rComments: The first lecture he essentially scared the hell out of everybody by ranting about how he will personally make sure his students are expelled for even the most minor academic offences committable in his classroom, just do not plagiarize. I also took PSY100 with Prof. V., he was an okay professor, slightly disorganized at times but not the worst.
teacherRatingTags: ["Skip class? You won't pass.", 'Tough grader', 'Test heavy']

rComments: he is a great and interesting lecturer, and gives good examples for students to understand concepts. however, his notes are full of typos and grammatical errors and are hard to understand. i think his tests are fair, but he doesn't give out any past or practice exams prior to the exams, which is unhelpful.

His classes are more cognitively tasking, but the way he teaches, respects, and engages students really inspires you to work harder and thus reap much more benefits. His test format and assignments allows for students to show what they understand in a very fair way.

Dr. Vervaeke is one of the best teachers I have ever had. He not only uses student participation and Aristotelian questioning method to ensure students' active engagement and thus, learning enhancement; He encourages responsibility, discovery and self-evaluation in his preparation of course material.  This is not a read and write test class.

Definitely the best prof I've had so far throughout my 3 years at U of T. Dr. Vervaeke is incredibly passionate about the content of this course and puts great effort into making sure his lectures are clear. He is a very down to earth and approachable lecturer and keeps class interesting by engaging in conversation with his students.

Dr. Vervaeke is a great lecturer, he is engaging and very fair.  It is refreshing to have a prof who genuinely cares about students experience and makes time to discuss and explain difficult subject matter.

Be ready to inquire about issues honestly. You must be curious about the material. He doesn't lay it all out for you: in order to demonstrate the principles of the course (insight problem-solving) you have to do some of the work and make the connections to see where he's going. No text: all readings of papers.
